habitat_description:
Lynx canadensis den sites are in mature or sapling spruce and fir forests with high horizontal cover and abundant coarse woody debris (Squires and Laurion, 2000; Organ et al., 2008; Squires et al., 2008). Throughout its range, the species’ primary prey is the snowshoe hare (Koehler, 1990; Ruggiero et al., 1999; Ruediger et al., 2000; Squires and Ruggiero, 2007).

In the western U.S., lynx forage in Englemann spruce-subalpine fir forests, lodgepole pine forests, and mesic mixed conifer forests with Douglas-fir, grand fir, aspen, larch, redcedar, or hemlock (Koehler, 1990; Ruediger et al., 2000; Koehler et al., 2008; Maletzke et al., 2008; Squires et al., 2010). Seventy-nine percent of documented occurrences were within spruce-fir, douglas-fir, and fir-hemlock forests (McKelvey et al., 2000). Lynx avoids low canopy cover, openings, clearcuts, burns, low understory cover, steep slopes, xeric sites, and ponderosa pine forests (Koehler, 1990; Koehler et al., 2008). In the Northwest, the species has seldom been recorded below an elevation of 915 m (Hudson, 1964; Koehler, 1990; Koehler et al., 2008; Squires et al., 2010), while in Colorado and Utah, minimum elevations of ~2400 m are suggested (Koehler and Brittell, 1990). Maximum elevations for the species are 2355 m in Montana (Squires et al., 2010), 2134 m in Washington (Koehler et al., 2008), to over 3750 m in Colorado (McKelvey et al., 2000).

In the Great Lakes region, lynx inhabit mixed or coniferous forests of balsam fir, black spruce, white spruce, northern white cedar, jack pine, red pine, white pine, hemlock, tamarack, aspen, and paper birch (Mech, 1980; Ruediger et al., 2000). Additionally, alder or willow shrub swamps and black spruce or tamarack bogs constitute suitable lynx habitat (Ruediger et al., 2000). Sugar maple-basswood, jack pine, and white pine-red pine forests have the highest frequencies of documented occurrence (McKelvey et al., 2000).

Northeastern populations of lynx prefer conifer-dominated sapling forests of white spruce, red spruce, balsam fir, black spruce, tamarack, hemlock, and northern white cedar with less frequent use of deciduous sapling stands including birch, aspen, beech, and sugar maple (Parker et al., 1983; Ruediger et al., 2000; Fuller et al., 2007; Organ et al., 2008; Vashon et al., 2008). In this region, the highest frequencies of documented occurrences were in red spruce-balsam fir and sugar maple-birch-beech forests (McKelvey et al., 2000). Mature forests are also sometimes used during the summer (Parker et al., 1983; Vashon et al., 2008).
